review: The book's convoluted narrative centers on Ava's amnesia and the mystery of her two-year marriage, but it falls short due to a lack of flashbacks and detailed explanations. The pacing is uneven, prioritizing current events over the past, which is essential for grasping their relationship. While the amnesia plotline is intriguing, it is not explored as deeply as in the author's previous works.

Eli King and Ava Nash were highly anticipated characters, yet their development felt rushed and incomplete. Their backstories, encompassing both childhood and adulthood, were only briefly mentioned, leaving readers wanting more. The narrative would have benefited from being divided into multiple parts to fully explore their relationship.

The author's writing style has been criticized for prioritizing telling over showing emotions. The harsh and aggressive interactions between Eli and Ava feel jarring, particularly in the context of their supposed love.

This book addresses serious themes such as mental health and psychosis, distinguishing it from the lighter tone of previous works. Eli's respectful treatment of Ava, particularly his choice to care for her personally and refrain from pressuring her, is commendable. However, the inclusion of other couples detracts from the central focus on Eli and Ava.
Ava's affectionate actions toward Eli were beautifully depicted, but Eli's perspective came across as impersonal and emotionally shallow.

While I had high hopes for this book, it ultimately fell short, leaving me disappointed. I appreciated the happy ending and was glad that Ava and Eli finally got their story, but I felt the journey could have been more rewarding. I look forward to a future reread in hopes of gaining a fresh perspective.
The author delayed the book's release, building high expectations, but ultimately, the execution did not meet them.
conclusion: The book, while long-awaited, did not meet the high expectations set by the anticipation of Eli and Ava's story. The character development felt rushed, the plot was convoluted, and the emotional depth was lacking. Despite these issues, I appreciated the serious themes and the respectful treatment of Ava by Eli. Overall, the book was a mixed experience, with moments of enjoyment overshadowed by a sense of disappointment.

review: I was intrigued by how Eli and Ava's story would compare to the darker narratives of others. While Eli is portrayed as unhinged like Lan, his madness manifests differently. He desperately strives to save his marriage and prevent his wife from spiraling away from him. Meanwhile, Ava battles her own demons, determined not to succumb to madness as she searches for everything she has lost.

Eli and Ava's story pleasantly surprised me with its heartbreakingly sweet and beautifully crafted love narrative. Throughout the book, it's evident that Ava holds more control over Eli than he does over her. Eli's character resonated with me, even though we learn very little about him; one thing is clear‚Äîhe loves Ava deeply. Both characters endure significant pain and suffering, and I genuinely felt for them. Their relationship stands out from the rest of the Legacy of Gods series, making it strong enough to hold its own. However, I would have loved to see a scene between Eli and Creighton after Ava's departure, as their brotherly bond is truly special.

This story showcases the author's remarkable talent! I will eagerly read any novel she publishes. I also appreciate when authors provide upfront information about the book's tone, whether it will be darker with trigger warnings or lighter than their usual works.

I was thrilled to receive this book, yet hesitant to start reading, knowing it would eventually come to an end. I can't deny that I cried at the conclusion, nor can I overlook how slowly I read to prolong my time in this captivating universe. I'm genuinely saddened that it's over, and I found myself emotional over the fate of this couple and their world. I'll conclude with a quote from the book, as it truly is a beautiful and heartfelt love story filled with passion.

I was thrilled to dive into the Cole chapter! Cole and Silver are my favorite couple; their journey has been filled with challenges, and their relationship had to remain hidden for so long. While we may or may not see a future for Remi and Ari, only time will tell. I did miss characters like Astrid, Levi, and Xan; their presence would have been a delightful bonus, even if they weren't essential to the story. I'm grateful for the moments we did get, and I always hold out hope for more unwritten stories. If not, there‚Äôs always the joy of rereading!
conclusion: This review expresses my deep emotional connection to the final installment, highlighting the beautiful and heartbreaking love story of Eli and Ava. I appreciate the author's skill in character development and storytelling, as well as the continuity and depth of the narrative. The review also reflects on my emotional response to the book and my anticipation for future works by the author.

review:
I had been eagerly anticipating EliAva's book since the SilverCole epilogue, and it did not disappoint. EliAva exceeded my expectations, and I adore them both. Eli captured my heart from his first appearance; I was surprised by his depth and the lengths he went to for Ava. Speaking of Ava, she is truly the "IT" girl, and my heart goes out to her‚Äîshe didn‚Äôt deserve everything she went through. Their banter and antics kept me completely engaged, and they perfectly complement each other's quirks.

One of my favorite aspects was Remiarie‚Äôs antics‚Äîshe is such a delightful menace! I found myself completely enamored with her and her hilarious shenanigans with Remi. That boy better watch out! 

As for SilverCole, their happiness with their families was heartwarming. Their bond remains strong, and their connection with their children is simply amazing. Cole truly shone in this story, especially as the father-in-law who actively tried to protect his daughter from a potential suitor. I also enjoyed the playful rivalry between him and Aiden; even after 30+ years, their banter is still entertaining. 

I was pleasantly surprised by how much I loved Aiden and Elsa in this installment‚Äîthey are fantastic parents. I even found myself intrigued by Jeremy, who finally got his happily ever after. Watching him grow into the man he is today was rewarding. 

Niko and Bran‚Äôs marriage was another highlight for me. Even with their limited time on the page, they made a significant impact, especially during that memorable scene where Niko clashed with Ari. I also appreciated Ava and Cecy‚Äôs friendship; they are each other‚Äôs support system, and Cecy‚Äôs help during Ava‚Äôs recovery was touching. 

Lastly, Landon was surprisingly entertaining, providing plenty of laughs with his antics. He was much more enjoyable here than in his own book. Overall, this story was a delightful read that left me wanting more!

I can hardly believe the Rinaverse has come to an end. It‚Äôs been a remarkable and sometimes tumultuous four-year journey, and I‚Äôve cherished every moment. I will truly miss the RES world, but at least I have the mafiaverse to look forward to.
conclusion: Overall, I absolutely loved everything else about the book, and I'm going to miss the characters and the world so much. Despite some minor critiques, the emotional journey, character development, and relationships made this a memorable and enjoyable read.

review: I was disappointed by the absence of a significant plot twist. The buildup in the first half sparked my curiosity, but the payoff fell flat. I anticipated more revelations, such as Ava recalling something crucial or Eli providing insights into past events, but ultimately, nothing shocking was revealed.

I adore both main characters, Eli and Ava. Eli's unwavering admiration for Ava's beauty is truly endearing, and his sacrifices for her are both heartbreaking and sweet, revealing a depth of feeling beneath his seemingly unfeeling exterior. The dynamic between Remi and Ari is another highlight; their relationship's progress is thrilling, and Ari's confidence and fierce nature make her a standout character. I would love to see the author write a book centered on Remi and Ari, as they are such an intriguing couple, even without trauma or mental illness as a central theme.
This book offers a refreshing departure from the typical college romance by exploring the dynamics of married life, making for an engaging change.

While Eli's struggles are alluded to, I would have appreciated a deeper exploration of his feelings, particularly during the two years Ava was losing herself. This could have added significant emotional depth and angst to the story. A more thorough examination of Eli's perspective, akin to the portrayal of Kirill's grief over Sasha's death in another book, would have made the narrative more impactful.

review: *God of War* distinguishes itself from other books through its remarkable depth, prompting reflection on every scene and dialogue. The antagonist, known as He-Who-Shall-Not-Be-Named, exhibits complex motivations that evoke a blend of heartwarming, heart-wrenching, and agitating emotions, enriching the narrative. However, certain elements, such as the lengthy bathroom description, felt superfluous and detracted from the story's emotional and psychological impact. Additionally, the numerous possession scenes could have been streamlined, as Eli's protective nature was already effectively established.

The author‚Äôs exploration of Ava‚Äôs mental health struggles is both unique and well-executed, providing a fresh perspective compared to other characters. I appreciated how Ava remained true to her bratty, provocative nature, consistent with her portrayal in previous books. Eli, despite his toxic traits, possesses a compelling duality; his sweetness offsets his red flags, making him intriguing. However, his initial thoughts about harming Ava after her trauma are unsettling and unhealthy. Landon‚Äôs appearance in this book was a highlight for me; I found him more enjoyable here than in his own standalone story.

The novel's ending was profoundly emotional, leaving me shaken and even in tears‚Äîa rarity for me. It felt like a bittersweet farewell to beloved characters like Lia, Adrian, Nikolai, and Brandon, who had truly captured my heart.
conclusion: *God of War* was a deeply emotional and thought-provoking experience, with standout character development and a unique exploration of mental health. While some pacing and content choices could have been improved, the novel left a lasting impact, making it a memorable read.

review: The story often felt overwhelming, cramming in too many events while ultimately lacking a sense of fulfillment. The ending, which revisited Aiden and Elsa‚Äôs son and employed the amnesia trope, came full circle but left much to be desired.

I enjoyed the moment when Eli finally called Ava "baby" and found his love confession endearing. I wished Eli had secretly harbored feelings for Ava all along, especially since he kissed her uncharacteristically when they were children. That epilogue moment lingered with me. The dynamic between Eli and Ava felt intense, and the story might have benefited from being a duet, as it seemed to contain both too much and too little at the same time. I didn't connect with the comparison between Eli and Aiden; I prefer to view them as distinct characters. Ava is portrayed as a goddess, an image that resonates powerfully‚Äîevery man with a pulse seems eager to worship her. One line that stood out was, "She looks like my own fucking angel. Broken wings and all," which struck me as both poetic and emotionally impactful.

I have several questions about the universe:

1. What happened to the Clifford bloodline? Who is Lord Clifford‚Äôs heir? Will it pass to Astrid‚Äôs children?
2. Why don‚Äôt Jeremy or any of the Heathens undergo Spetznas training like Adrian and Kirill?
3. Is Knox the Bratva‚Äôs main lawyer? What do Kingsley, Nate, and Dan think of his role? Why hasn‚Äôt Knox‚Äôs child been mentioned?
4. Is Sergei Sokolov dead?
5. Remi and Ariella‚Äôs story had potential, especially with the female stalker dynamic.
6. Vaughn Morozov and Maya Sokolov‚Äôs potential relationship could be explosive, given their personalities and histories.
7. Vaughn‚Äôs initiation scene with the chain was incredibly hot, even without knowing his appearance.
8. GOW could have been a standalone, as it felt disconnected from the main storyline.
9. How are the mafia children allowed to have Instagram accounts and tag each other? Their connections to public figures seem like a security risk.
10. Where is Damien and Mio‚Äôs book? It feels overdue.
conclusion: While the novel had some standout romantic moments and memorable quotes, the plot felt overcrowded and lacked fulfillment. The world-building left many questions unanswered, and certain character dynamics and storylines had untapped potential. Despite these issues, I was invested enough to stay engaged throughout the ride.

review: The novel presents a complex and emotionally charged narrative centered on a protagonist grappling with depression and psychosis. Her life takes a dramatic turn when she confesses her love to a man who harshly rejects her. Over the next four years, he secretly sabotages her relationships, culminating in a traumatic attempted sexual assault. In a fit of rage, he kills her attacker and coerces her into a marriage of convenience. Their relationship remains strained and devoid of intimacy for two years, until a violent confrontation results in her memory loss. As time passes, she begins to develop feelings for him again, though her mental health struggles continue. Following a series of intense events, she seeks treatment, leading to a more positive and loving dynamic between them. The pacing is deliberate, featuring significant time jumps that underscore the evolution of their relationship and personal challenges. The structure alternates between moments of high tension and quieter, introspective periods, enhancing the emotional depth of the story.

The protagonist struggles with depression and psychosis, which profoundly influence her actions and decisions. The male lead is a complex character, exhibiting both protective and controlling traits. His journey transforms him from cold and distant to vulnerable and caring, particularly as he supports her recovery.

The novel tackles profound themes of mental illness, trauma, manipulation, and redemption. Its emotional depth is striking, capturing moments of despair, conflict, and eventual healing. The narrative intricately explores the complexities of love, forgiveness, and personal growth.
conclusion: This novel is a rollercoaster of emotions, blending dark themes with moments of redemption and love. The characters' journeys are compelling, and the story's exploration of mental health and trauma adds depth. While the relationship starts on a toxic note, it evolves into a more hopeful and fulfilling dynamic. The explicit romantic elements cater to readers who enjoy intense and passionate storytelling.

review: The book felt lacking in action compared to others, leading to moments of boredom. Although there were some intense scenes, the overall plot seemed uneventful. The wedding scene was particularly disappointing, as it was described poorly; I would have preferred a more uplifting portrayal of Eli and Ava's special day. Additionally, the forced marriage and murder subplot felt out of place and detracted from the story's overall coherence.

Cole's treatment of Eli was both frustrating and unnecessary. His grudge against Eli felt petty and immature, which was disappointing given my usual admiration for Cole. While Eli serves as a villain for much of the book, he ultimately reveals himself to be caring and thoughtful. Unfortunately, the mysterious aura he had in previous installments is lost, and his secrets are too easily uncovered. 

Ava's character was equally disappointing; she often came across as a spoiled brat, and her lack of maturity was frustrating, especially considering her age. Her revenge plot against Eli never materialized, which felt like a missed opportunity. Although the tension between Eli and Ava was palpable and they shared some cute moments, their relationship felt underdeveloped. The forced marriage aspect was difficult to reconcile with their characters. While the book included some steamy scenes, the romantic development between Eli and Ava fell short of the expectations set by earlier couples.
The writing featured some beautifully crafted lines and intense scenes, but overall, it did not meet the high standard I typically expect from this author.
conclusion: Overall, this book didn‚Äôt meet my high expectations. While it had its moments, the lack of action, inconsistent character development, and underdeveloped romantic dynamics left me feeling disappointed. I still have mixed feelings about it and may need more time to fully process my thoughts. My final ranking of the couples reflects my disappointment with Eli and Ava‚Äôs story.

review: The plot twist was predictable and underwhelming, lacking the excitement I anticipated. The book often dragged, making it hard to stay engaged, and the pacing was inconsistent, with several moments feeling unnecessarily prolonged.

**Ava:** Ava initially stood out as a funny, sassy, and strong character, and I was eager to see her relationship with Eli develop. Unfortunately, she became a disappointment, transforming into a doormat who accepted Eli's cruel behavior without asserting herself. Her attempts at retaliation through petty pranks felt ineffective and undermined her original strength. 

**Eli King:** Eli began as a mysterious, brooding figure, which initially intrigued me. However, he quickly became unlikable due to his rude, manipulative, and invasive actions, such as coercing Ava into marriage and installing a hidden camera in her bathroom. His double standards‚Äîhooking up with other women while restricting Ava's dating life‚Äîfurther tarnished his character. The tension in their relationship felt frustrating rather than compelling, as Eli's manipulative behavior and Ava's lack of empowerment created an imbalanced dynamic. Ultimately, Eli's control and Ava's passivity were major letdowns.

The book was overhyped, and unfortunately, it didn't meet my high expectations. I recommend approaching it with low expectations to avoid disappointment. The mixed reviews I encountered were accurate, and my experience leaned more toward the negative feedback.
conclusion: While the book had its moments, particularly with Ava's initial charm and the heartwarming epilogue, it ultimately fell short of my expectations. The characters, especially Eli, became increasingly unlikable, and the plot lacked the excitement and depth I had hoped for. The pacing issues and predictable twists further diminished my enjoyment. Overall, it was a disappointing read, and I would advise others to approach it with caution.

review: The book's slow pace and repetitive nature left much to be desired, with a plot that ultimately fell flat despite a few surprising moments. However, I particularly enjoyed the chapter featuring Jer and Cecy‚Äôs wedding, which hinted at Vaughn‚Äôs intriguing potential storyline.

Eli and Ava's tension in the first book was among the strongest I've encountered, and their teasing had fans buzzing with excitement. Unfortunately, this sequel fell short of expectations. Ava Nash, once a vibrant character, disappointed me here. While she promised revenge, she mostly squandered Eli's money and crashed his car, coming off as a spoiled brat. Aside from exposing Gemma, which I appreciated, she didn't assert herself much. Her character lacked the sass and strength of her parents, Silver and Cole. 

Eli, who was intriguing in previous installments, also let me down. He slut-shamed Ava and dismissed her, though he did show some improvement by the end. Their relationship felt lackluster, despite a few cute moments and enjoyable banter. Ava's attempts to annoy Eli by seducing him were entertaining, and I was relieved that the author preserved her relationship with Ari, which I really liked. 

Eli and Cray remained the cutest sibling duo, and the dynamics among the King brothers were intact. However, Glyndon's absence during Ava's darkest moments further diminished my view of her character. On a positive note, Annika and Cecy were supportive friends, and Ari stood out with his humor and threats directed at half the cast, including Nikolai.
conclusion: While Eli and Ava‚Äôs story had potential, it fell short of expectations. Ava‚Äôs character lacked the strength and sass of her parents, and Eli‚Äôs behavior was often disappointing. The slow pacing, repetitive chapters, and lack of action made the book less engaging. However, the supporting characters, particularly Ari, and the preservation of the King brothers‚Äô dynamics were highlights. The wedding chapter and hints at Vaughn‚Äôs story were enjoyable, but overall, this book didn‚Äôt meet my expectations.

Ava Nash shares some traits with Lia from the "Deception Trilogy," yet she distinctly carves out her own identity. However, Eli's thoughtfulness towards Ava and his efforts to allow her to experience life on her own terms resonated with me, even if I didn't fully agree with his methods.
The book features a poetic and intense tone, exemplified by lines such as, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not a knight in shining armor. What I am, however, is the only man who‚Äôs allowed near her.‚Äù

The emotional depth in moments such as, ‚ÄúFor a moment, my whole world goes black. And I know, I just know, that if she‚Äôs gone, I‚Äôll make sure it‚Äôs the end for me as well,‚Äù is profoundly impactful.
Eli's approach to securing the marriage was both humorous and entertaining, enhancing the overall enjoyment of the story.
The author has reused plotlines, resulting in a story reminiscent of the "Deception Trilogy," albeit with different characters.
conclusion: Overall, I was pleasantly surprised by the book, even though I initially struggled with the chemistry between the main characters. While the plot felt recycled and the marriage premise was weak, Eli‚Äôs thoughtfulness and the emotional moments stood out. review: I was taken aback by Ava‚Äôs condition, which hadn‚Äôt been mentioned in the previous books. This unexpected twist set the story apart from the others. While I appreciated the book, it was a challenging read that left me feeling unsettled compared to the other Log books. The amnesia trope reminded me of some of the author‚Äôs previous works; although it‚Äôs not my favorite, I trusted her to handle it well. However, the first half of the book felt confusing, and the tension between the characters didn‚Äôt resonate with me. I expected emotional depth, but instead, Eli seemed solely focused on possessing Ava, while she struggled to understand her situation.

Eli, whom I expected to be a standout character, ultimately fell short of my expectations. For the first 80% of the book, I found his interactions with Ava off-putting, particularly his excessive possessiveness. While I could understand his behavior to some extent, it often crossed the line, such as when he forbade her from touching her friends. I only began to like Eli near the end, at the 95% mark, but it was too little, too late to redeem the book for me. My main issue seems to stem from the author‚Äôs writing style; I noticed a tendency to repeat certain dynamics between couples, which I hadn‚Äôt found bothersome before but became quite apparent in this story.

This book did not meet my expectations, and I was disappointed. I was eager to dive into Ava and Eli's story, but it ultimately fell short. Although it can be read as a standalone, it felt disconnected from the rest of the collection. Having read the first and third books, this installment seemed out of place.
conclusion: Overall, this book was a letdown compared to my expectations. While I appreciated some aspects, such as Eli‚Äôs redemption near the end, the excessive possessiveness, lack of emotional tension, and unexpected plot elements left me feeling disappointed. It was a hard read, and while I still liked it, it didn‚Äôt deliver the story I had envisioned.

review: The amnesia trope was well-executed, yet I still found it unappealing. The arranged marriage plot felt poorly developed and failed to resonate with me. Overall, the storyline felt disjointed and lacking the chaos and depth I anticipated, especially in comparison to *Ruthless Empire*. Ava's illness appeared abruptly, with no prior mention in earlier books, which was frustrating. Additionally, certain plot points, such as Ava's encounter with Eli's mother, were introduced but never fully explored, leaving unsatisfying loose ends.

Eli King emerged as my favorite character, and I thoroughly enjoyed his scenes. His possessiveness and obsession with Ava were compelling, though at times, his love felt unhealthy. Ava, despite being 23, often came across as immature and cringeworthy, making the noticeable age gap with Eli hard to overlook. Aiden was a supportive father, and I appreciated Adrian's affection for Cecily. Cecy, Jeremy, Elsa, and Silver were also standout characters, though I wished NikoBran and JerCecy had more screen time. Unfortunately, the chemistry between Eli and Ava felt lacking, and even the intimate scenes fell flat and felt uncomfortable.

The writing style evokes nostalgia, reminiscent of earlier works like *AdrianLia*, which stirs fond memories but also detracts from the book's originality. The pacing is uneven, oscillating between intense drama‚Äîsuch as Eli's stabbing‚Äîand abrupt shifts, like Ava's birthday celebration and the arrival of triplets. This creates a disjointed, fever dream-like quality to the narrative.
The book felt disjointed, as if the characters inhabited a different universe, which hindered my ability to fully immerse myself in the story.
The emotional depth of Eli and Ava's relationship was inconsistent. Although Eli's monologues about his love for Ava were intense, their overall connection felt neither genuine nor well-developed.
conclusion: While I enjoyed Eli‚Äôs character and the nostalgic writing style, the book fell short in several areas. The plot felt disjointed, the chemistry between the main characters was lacking, and the story's connection to previous events was weak. Despite these flaws, I appreciated the glimpses of other beloved characters and the emotional moments that reminded me of earlier works by the author. Overall, it was a mixed experience that left me feeling conflicted.

review: The first 30% of the book showed promise, but the story soon lost momentum and became tedious. The plot lacked major twists and engaging developments, and the pacing was slow, especially compared to the author‚Äôs previous fast-paced, binge-worthy works. The twist involving Helen was particularly disappointing, revealing itself to be a mere hallucination rather than a significant plot development.

Eli King comes across as bland and emotionally disconnected, lacking depth and making his attempts to run King and Steel Corp feel more like a joke than a serious endeavor. Ava, on the other hand, embodies the typical romance novel archetype: a blonde virgin with a weak personality. Her character arc is repetitive and uninspired, often portraying her as childish and overly dependent on others. The sibling dynamics in the author‚Äôs works are generally underdeveloped, with only a few pairs, such as Jeremy and Annika or Creighton and Eli, feeling authentic. 

Eli and Ava's relationship lacks chemistry, and their on-again, off-again dynamic quickly becomes tiresome. Their romance feels forced, lacking genuine passion, and the sex scenes are disappointingly vanilla. While cameos from previous characters like Creighton, Annika, Jeremy, and Cecy provide some enjoyment, the reliance on familiar faces feels more like a crutch than a strength. Additionally, side characters like Glyn and Landon are poorly written and unlikable, further detracting from the overall experience.

This book's writing style diverges from the author's previous works, attempting a poetic flair that ultimately falls flat. The descriptions often veer into the absurd and over-the-top, detracting from the narrative. An overreliance on certain words, such as "alien," and repetitive phrases, particularly Ava's incessant quest for revenge, render the writing feel lazy and uninspired. The author leans heavily on familiar tropes‚Äîvirgin heroines, alpha male heroes, and mental health struggles‚Äîresulting in a sense of repetition and lack of originality. The characters' emotional baggage often feels recycled from earlier books, and the "magical healing" trope, where the male lead resolves the female lead's issues through love and sex, is both overused and problematic.
conclusion: This book was a major disappointment, especially after a two-year wait. The characters lacked depth, the plot was weak, and the writing style felt off compared to the author‚Äôs previous works. The repetitive tropes and problematic portrayal of women further detracted from the story. While there were a few enjoyable moments, overall, the book failed to live up to expectations.

The author's writing in this book was disappointing, especially given how enjoyable the first three LOG books were. The last three, particularly *God of Ruin* and *God of Malice*, felt chaotic. The plot was vague and overly mysterious, which ultimately backfired. It seemed as though the author aimed for intrigue but missed the mark entirely.

The marriage of convenience trope was poorly executed, missing a valuable opportunity for deeper exploration. The dynamic between Ava and Eli was both dull and absurd, lacking depth and becoming repetitive. Overall, their relationship fell flat and failed to engage.

I had high hopes for *God of Malice* due to the intriguing tension between Ava and Eli, anticipating it would be the best in the series. Unfortunately, it fell short of my expectations. I had hoped to see the author's writing evolve, but it felt recycled and disappointing, especially when compared to her earlier works like *God of Pain* and *God of War*.

review: The plot twists and revelations about the past were disappointing and lacked impact. While the comparison between Eli's manipulation of Ava's mental health and Adrian's manipulation of Lia in another book was notable, I found Eli to be far more despicable.

I found Eli to be intensely unlikable due to his derogatory behavior and treatment of Ava, whom he reduced to a mere "fuck buddy" despite being his wife. Ava's lack of assertiveness and her desperation in the face of Eli's mistreatment made her a doormat heroine, a portrayal I strongly dislike. The book's blatant double standards and misogyny were particularly striking. Eli's supposed obsession with Ava since college felt misleading, especially since the narrative suggests he slept with other women after she enrolled at university. Their relationship was toxic, with Eli's actions exacerbating Ava's mental health struggles. The absence of a genuine emotional connection and Eli's dismissive attitude toward Ava's desires‚Äîsuch as ignoring her wish to have a baby‚Äîwere significant red flags.

The book perpetuates troubling themes, including the glorification of male promiscuity and the expectation of female virginity. The pervasive misogynistic undertones and double standards are both disappointing and concerning.

I found this book incredibly dull, to the point of nearly weeping from boredom. Finishing it felt like a chore. The only thing that kept me going was listening to music by Anitta and Little Mix, which I typically avoid while reading due to distractions.
conclusion: Overall, this was a very disappointing read and a poor conclusion. The toxic dynamics, misogynistic themes, and lackluster plot twists made it a struggle to get through. While there were a few redeeming moments, they were not enough to salvage the book. I‚Äôm taking an indefinite break from the author‚Äôs works unless there‚Äôs a significant shift in how female characters and relationships are portrayed.

review: The plot lacks excitement and originality, offering minimal suspense or romantic tension. It reads more like an instruction manual than a captivating story. The slow pacing, combined with repetitive dialogue and descriptions, makes it challenging to remain engaged.

Eli and Ava, the main characters, are poorly developed and lack depth, feeling more like recycled versions of previous characters (Adrianlia, Reinaasher) than original creations. Ava comes across as a spoiled brat, with her attempts at being a badass feeling unconvincing. Her amnesia and mental illness serve merely as plot devices, failing to add meaningful complexity to her character. Eli, on the other hand, is reduced to a one-dimensional figure, constantly growling possessive phrases and lacking the intelligence and manipulation expected of a sociopath. His stalking and obsession feel forced and unoriginal. 

The chemistry between Eli and Ava is virtually nonexistent, lacking any emotional depth and resembling the sexual tension of a piece of broccoli. Their relationship appears to be a poorly executed attempt to replicate the success of previous couples. In contrast, the side characters‚Äîsuch as Remiari, Aiden, and Elsa‚Äîare more compelling and deserve greater focus. Their interactions and banter provide much-needed relief from the main plot and are the true highlights of the book.

The writing suffers from excessive repetition and clich√©d expressions, frequently using phrases like "stormy," "mysterious," and "cold eyes." The narrative lacks originality, as the author appears to recycle elements from previous works instead of crafting something new.
conclusion: This book was a major disappointment, failing to live up to its hype. The main characters, Eli and Ava, were poorly developed and lacked chemistry, while the plot was dull and repetitive. The side characters and their interactions were the only saving grace, but they were not given enough attention. The writing style was clich√©d and uninspired, making it a struggle to finish. Overall, the book felt like a missed opportunity, especially with the potential of characters like Remiari.

review: The plot seemed recycled from the author's earlier works, yet it was still preferable to having no plot at all. The story had promise, particularly when Ava acknowledged my criticisms early on, but ultimately, it fell short in execution.

Ava's character began with promise but was ultimately let down by a narrative that inadequately addressed her mental health struggles. Her relationship with her parents, especially her father Cole, was poignant yet unresolved, creating emotional gaps in her story. Ava's happy ending felt rushed and unconvincing, as her underlying issues were merely glossed over rather than truly resolved. Eli's character presented problems, including instances of slut-shaming and controlling behavior that went unaddressed and unapologized for. While there were moments that showcased his care for Ava, his character arc felt underdeveloped.

The character banter was enjoyable, but the dialogue, particularly in the intimate scenes, often felt awkward. The author should approach serious topics, especially mental health, with greater research and sensitivity.

The recurring trope of inexperienced female protagonists paired with overly experienced male leads is both concerning and repetitive. Additionally, the treatment of mental health issues felt superficial and lacked the necessary depth, which was disappointing given the seriousness of the subject.
conclusion: While the book had moments of potential, particularly in Ava‚Äôs character and the initial setup, it ultimately fell short due to poor handling of serious themes, repetitive tropes, and underdeveloped character arcs. The dialogue and smut scenes often felt cringe-worthy, and the resolution of Ava‚Äôs struggles was unsatisfying. Despite some emotional moments, the book failed to deliver a compelling or well-rounded story, leading to a lower rating.

He unjustly blames Cecily for Ava's mental health struggles, despite Cecily's supportive role in Ava's life. Eli's alarming threats of violence, including contemplating breaking Ava's neck and threatening Mia Sokolov, reveal his abusive and controlling nature. The only redeeming aspect of Eli is his relationship with his brother, Creighton, who genuinely cares for and supports Ava during her darkest moments. In contrast, Cecily serves as a nurturing figure, highlighting Eli's toxic behavior. Mia Sokolov, an innocent character, becomes a target of Eli's threats, further underscoring his antagonism.
The novel delves into themes of abuse, manipulation, and mental health struggles; however, Eli's character ultimately overshadows any possibility of redemption or growth.

The backstory of Eli and Ava was beautifully crafted, showcasing Eli's protective obsession with Ava since childhood, viewing her as his princess. However, in the final book, Ava's character undergoes a drastic transformation; she becomes severely mentally ill, an alcoholic, and a drug addict, which feels inconsistent with her earlier portrayal. Eli's character also suffers, shifting from an obsessive lover to someone who finds Ava annoying and insignificant. The romantic tension that once defined their relationship is entirely absent, replaced by nonsensical and tiresome conversations. Their interactions lack genuine emotional connection or development, with Eli appearing cold and dismissive, while Ava comes off as desperate and erratic. The resolution of their relationship‚Äîculminating in marriage and triplets‚Äîfeels contrived and ultimately unsatisfying.

review: The revelation that Eli saved Ava from assault and forced her into marriage felt contrived and lacked the emotional depth necessary for impact. Their two-year marriage was barely explored, leaving a significant gap in their story. Overall, the book felt like a lackluster sendoff, with even the enjoyable character interactions failing to elicit much reaction. The conclusion was unsatisfying, and while moments like KG backpacking, Cranni's cuteness, and Lan and Mia's surprising longevity were enjoyable, they couldn't redeem the overall disappointment. The Tuscany wedding for JC and NB was a sweet touch, but it ultimately fell short of compensating for the book's flaws.

Ava's character is primarily defined by her relationship with Eli, lacking depth beyond being his love interest. During their marriage, she is isolated from friends and family, leading to her unhappiness. Eli himself is unlikable and dull; his obsession with Ava feels superficial, and his derogatory comments about her clothing and behavior make him come across as more of a loser than a compelling character.

The dynamics within the Kings family are disappointing. Despite being the author's favorites, they never share a scene together, unlike the Sokolov/Carsons family, whose relationships are both genuine and relatable in their dysfunction. The mafia side relationships, such as Niko and Jer's friendship and the Heathens' strong bond, are far more engaging and well-developed than those of the main characters. While Eli and Aiden's relationship falls flat, others like Jer and Adrian, Niko and Kyle, and Bran and Levi shine as strong father-son duos. 

Remi and Ari's relationship is confusing and unsatisfying, feeling one-sided with Remi consistently pushing Ari away. Nash's obsession with women is portrayed negatively, which is off-putting. In contrast, JC and NB's relationship is filled with love and warmth, highlighting the stark difference between Ava's fear and misery in her marriage to Eli. 

Niko and Bran's relationship stands out, showcasing mutual obsession and possessiveness, with tender moments like Niko resting his chin on Bran's shoulder adding depth. Overall, the Sokolov/Carsons family emerges as a more cohesive and engaging unit compared to the Kings. Side characters like Cecy and Jer share a strong, supportive bond, with Jer always by Cecy's side, while Xander and Adrian's friendly dynamic offers a refreshing contrast, likely influenced by Cecy.
conclusion: The book fell short of expectations, with weak character development, poorly executed plot points, and a lackluster conclusion. While some relationships and side characters provided enjoyable moments, the main storyline and central characters (especially Eli and Ava) were underwhelming and frustrating. The mafia side relationships and the Sokolov/Carsons family dynamics were the saving graces, but they weren't enough to redeem the book as a whole.
